ncmw.community.community_analysis module¶

ncmw.community.community_analysis.community_weight_posterior(model, enforce_survival=0.0, num_simulations=10000, cooperative_tradeoff=None, noise=0.05, prior='dirichlet')[source]¶
ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_community_interaction_graph(model, df)[source]¶

Compute a graph that displays the community interaction. We say that model i interacts with model j if i produces something that j needs, but is not provided by the medium! We consider each pair of external metabolites and connect them by this criterium.

Parameters

  • model – Cobra model

  • df – A summary file i.e. that returned by model.summary()

Returns

Interaction graph df: Relevant summary

Return type

Graph

ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_community_summary(community_model, weights)[source]¶
ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_dominant_weights(community_model: ncmw.community.community_models.CommunityModel, high_val: float = 0.9) → List[numpy.array][source]¶

For each community member we compute the weight in which one of the members has a dominant weight. For example if \(m_i\) is the dominant model then \(w_i =\)

Parameters

  • community_model (CommunityModel) – A community model

  • high_val (float) – The largest weight value

Returns

List of weigt vector, for any member of the community. In each vector one member can be thought as “dominant”

Return type

List[np.array]

ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_fair_weights(community_model: ncmw.community.community_models.CommunityModel) → numpy.array[source]¶

Compute fair weights, fair in the sense that organisms with high single growth has a low weights such that all species have the same weighted MBR. More precisely if \(G_i\) is the growth of model i, the corresponding unnormalized weight is defined as

\[w_i = 1/(G_i +1e-32)\]

We then normalize the vector such that \(\sum_i w_i = 1\)

Parameters

community_model – Cobra Model

Returns

Numpy array of weights

Return type

array

ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_pairwise_growth_relation_per_weight(community_model: ncmw.community.community_models.CommunityModel, idx1: int, idx2: int, h: int = 200) → Tuple[numpy.array, numpy.array, numpy.array][source]¶

We compare the pairwise growth relation as following: Be \(\alpha \in [0,1]\) and \(G_i, G_j\) the growth expression for model i and j. Then we maximize the community objective \(\alpha G_i + (1-\alpha)G_j\) and report the growth values.

Parameters

  • community_model – Community model

  • idx1 – Index of community member which is tested

  • idx2 – Index of second community member which is tested

  • h – Number of growth evaluations, for different weights.

Returns

The values of \(\alpha\) on which we the growths. np.array: The growth values of the first model. np.array: The growth values of the second model.

Return type

np.array

ncmw.community.community_analysis.compute_species_interaction_weights(model: ncmw.community.community_models.CommunityModel, df: pandas.core.frame.DataFrame, alpha: float = 1.0)[source]¶

Compute interaction between two species. The values lie between -1 (negative interaction) and + 1 postitive interaction. Be \(p_{ij}\) the number of metabolites produced by i and consumed by j. Be \(c_{ij}\) the number of metabolites consumed by both i and j. Then we compute the interaction as

\[w_{ij} = w_i* ( p_{ij}/\sum_k p_{ik} - c_{ij}/\sum_k c_{ik})\]
Parameters

  • model – Communiy model

  • df – Summary table

  • alpha – Parameter for postive interaction, larger implies that postive interaction is wheighted more.

Returns

N x N matrix of interaction weights between species.

Return type

np.array

ncmw.community.community_models module¶

class ncmw.community.community_models.BagOfReactionsModel(models: list)[source]¶

Bases: ncmw.community.community_models.CommunityModel

This is a community model, which treats the community as a bag of all reactions that at least one the species has.

compute_COOPM(MBR, fraction=0.1, enforce_survival=0.1)[source]¶

Computes the COOPM medium

compute_convex_combination(alphas, maxbiomass=0.1)[source]¶
cooperative_tradeoff(alpha: float = 0.9)[source]¶
Performs a cooperative tradeoff optimization strategy, which requires two

steps: First a FBA solution is obtain, we call it MBR. Then we minimize the L2 norm of a vector containing all individual growths under the constraint that the community objective is greater than \(lpha \cdot MBR\)

Parameters

alpha – Tradeoff value, must be between 0 and 1.

Returns

Value of the community objective individual_growth: List of individual growths solution: Cobra solution object, containing fluxes for all reactions

Return type

community_growth

flux_variability_analysis(loopless=False, fraction_of_optimum=1.0, pfba_factor=None, processes=None)[source]¶

Determine the minimum and maximum possible flux value for each reaction.

Parameters: loopless (boolean, optional):

Whether to return only loopless solutions. This is significantly slower. Please also refer to the notes.

fraction_of_optimum (float, optional) :

Must be <= 1.0. Requires that the objective value is at least the fraction times maximum objective value. A value of 0.85 for instance means that the objective has to be at least at 85% percent of its maximum.

pfba_factor (float, optional):

Add an additional constraint to the model that requires the total sum of absolute fluxes must not be larger than this value times the smallest possible sum of absolute fluxes, i.e., by setting the value to 1.1 the total sum of absolute fluxes must not be more than 10% larger than the pFBA solution. Since the pFBA solution is the one that optimally minimizes the total flux sum, the pfba_factor should, if set, be larger than one. Setting this value may lead to more realistic predictions of the effective flux bounds.

processes (int, optional):

The number of parallel processes to run. If not explicitly passed, will be set from the global configuration singleton.

Returns pandas.DataFrame

A data frame with reaction identifiers as the index and two columns: - maximum: indicating the highest possible flux - minimum: indicating the lowest possible flux

Performs FBA on the community model

Parameters

  • enforce_survival – Must be between 0 and 1. It constraint the community such

  • all member must have atleast X % of the community growth e.g. if (that) –

  • survival=1 then all members must have the same fraction of the total (enforce) –

  • growth. –

Returns

Value of the community objective individual_growth: List of individual growths solution: Cobra solution object, containing fluxes for all reactions

summary(enforce_survival: float = 0, cooperative_tradeoff: Optional[float] = None)[source]¶
Creates a community summary. We list all exchanges between members of the

community and between the environment.

Parameters

  • enforce_survival – Enforce a minimium percentage of growth for each member.

  • cooperative_tradeoff – Perform cooperative tradeoff.

Returns

Table of fluxes.

Return type

pd.DataFrame
